etymologies: late Middle English (also in the sense ‘ambergris’): from Old French ambre, from Arabic ‘anbar ‘ambergris’, later ‘amber’

definitions: hard translucent fossilized resin produced by extinct coniferous trees of the Tertiary period, typically yellowish in color.

notes.text: Amber has been used in jewelry since antiquity. It is found chiefly along the southern shores of the Baltic Sea; pieces often contain the bodies of trapped insects. When rubbed, amber becomes charged with static electricity: the word electric is derived from the Greek word for amber

definitions: a honey-yellow color typical of amber

examples.text: her eyes were green flecked with amber

definitions: a yellow light used as a cautionary signal between green for “go” and red for “stop”
shortDefinitions: yellow light used as cautionary traffic signal
